headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Steve, in your prepared comments, you talked a little bit about some of your new growth initiatives and one that you touched on was advisor-based managed portfolios. I was hoping you could provide a little bit more color on that, and then just address the
componenttext: Steve, in your prepared comments, you talked a little bit about some of your new growth initiatives and one that you touched on was advisor-based managed portfolios. I was hoping you could provide a little bit more color on that, and then just address the bigger issue where if you look at some of the larger competitors in the space, the firms that are growing the client asset the fastest certainly have the advisor businesses. So kind of how do you think about maybe trying to establish a bigger beachhead into that area?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me answer and Mike Curcio here who runs the Brokerage side and Mike should feel free to add his comments as well. On the RAA [ph] (56:29) business, it hasn't been a business that we've been in in the past and our business model really has been one tha
componenttext: Let me answer and Mike Curcio here who runs the Brokerage side and Mike should feel free to add his comments as well. On the RAA [ph] (56:29) business, it hasn't been a business that we've been in in the past and our business model really has been one that's direct to the customer. And so not disagreeing but it's a fast or growing segment of the broader industry. It just hasn't been an area that we've pursued. So it's something that again, we would consider. But in the world of privatization its not high on our list of priorities, at least over the intermediate term. In contrast, for example, we would much prefer to rev up our corporate services group and grow more rapidly there, then basically enter an area that is costly to enter and will take a long time in our view to get aggregate profitability. So we just have to be conscious not only of the opportunity but the cost of entry, and what alternatives are. And again, because of it wasn't central to the business model over time, I'll never say never, but I don't want to mislead anybody to say that we're going to jump into that area. From the standpoint of the managed investment products and the like, I'll let Mike comment on that as to what we have in the marketplace, how we basically have distributed those products and what some of the near-term opportunities are in that particular space as we tried to basically service both the investment needs of our clients in addition to what we historically done, which has been predominantly the trading needs of our clients.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve. This is Mike. On the MITs or managed investment portfolios, we first started with a very simple wrap, ETF and mutual fund accounts that were extended to, we will be extending it to separately managed accounts in late Q4, early Q1 of next ye
componenttext: Thanks, Steve. This is Mike. On the MITs or managed investment portfolios, we first started with a very simple wrap, ETF and mutual fund accounts that were extended to, we will be extending it to separately managed accounts in late Q4, early Q1 of next year. What we've seen is a tremendous appetite from our customer base. We're hitting our target numbers and in conjunction with the rapidly expanding our sales force, we're very optimistic of a lot more penetration in assets in MIT's as well as our Mutual Fund business overall.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me just go back just to add to the commentary because it may have been missed. It's what I've said in my opening comments, that we've worked through a segmentation of our portfolio. And basically, I would say in our most compelling segments, what Mike
componenttext: Let me just go back just to add to the commentary because it may have been missed. It's what I've said in my opening comments, that we've worked through a segmentation of our portfolio. And basically, I would say in our most compelling segments, what Mike and team have been doing is adding relational sales capability. And in the addition to the relational sales capability, the products and services that would better serve, not only the trading needs but the investment needs of our customers as well, and it's a fairly virtuous cycle that they basically broaden their relationship with us, we can fulfill more of their needs. But in addition to that, we can begin to diversify just from the transaction orientation on the Brokerage side to one that gives us an actuarial stream in addition because of essentially the management fees that come along with those particular product.

componenttextpreview: Sure. This is Bob Burton, I'll answer that one. We have been very aggressive since 2007 in putting back loans to customers. We put back about $263 million of loans so far. Obviously as the portfolio ages, our opportunity to put those loans back become som
componenttext: Sure. This is Bob Burton, I'll answer that one. We have been very aggressive since 2007 in putting back loans to customers. We put back about $263 million of loans so far. Obviously as the portfolio ages, our opportunity to put those loans back become somewhat smaller. But we continue to work with the original sellers to put back loans to them. We've done about $40 million this year. So it is falling down. But at the same time, we are also talking to a variety of original sellers about settlements of that right, and there's some opportunity there. In terms of who the sellers were, it really cuts across all of the people that were heavy originated of loans during that period. And so there's no particular concentration in any one originator. It really is pretty indicative of the market during those years.

componenttextpreview: This is Steve again. Let me just kind of give perspective without, again, giving numbers. Clearly, the industry-wide softness we experienced we think are in line with basically with expectations. That said, the early part of the fourth quarter, really bas
componenttext: This is Steve again. Let me just kind of give perspective without, again, giving numbers. Clearly, the industry-wide softness we experienced we think are in line with basically with expectations. That said, the early part of the fourth quarter, really basically the first 20 days or so of October, we've seen basically a fair amount of resiliency in trading activity without getting into specificity. So we're not declaring basically that it's the point of inflection post the flash crash. But on the other hand, it does make us feel a little bit more confident that, I would say, the retail client or the retail customer possibly is feeling well enough to wade back into maybe the shallow end of the pool. But that said, it's still very early days. But I'd rather be seeing the trend we're seeing in the first part of the quarter than not. I don't know if that answers it but that's the best we could say at the moment.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you.  Good afternoon and thank you for joining us for E*TRADE Financials Third Quarter 2010 Conference Call.  Joining me today are Steven Freiburg, E*TRADEs Chief Executive Officer, Bruce Nolop, our Chief Financial Officer, and other members o
componenttext:
Thank you.  Good afternoon and thank you for joining us for E*TRADE Financials Third Quarter 2010 Conference Call.  Joining me today are Steven Freiburg, E*TRADEs Chief Executive Officer, Bruce Nolop, our Chief Financial Officer, and other members of E*TRADEs management team.
Before turning the call over to Steve, Id like to remind everyone that during this conference call, the company will be sharing with you certain projections for other forward-looking statements regarding future events or its future performance.
E*TRADE Financial cautions you that certain factors including risks and uncertainties referred to in the 10Ks, 10Qs, and other documents E*TRADE files with the Securities and Exchange Commission could cause the companys actual results to defer materially from what is indicated on its highest projects for forward-looking statements.
This call will present information as of October 20th, 2010.  Please note that E*TRADE FINANCIAL dispoints any duty to update any forward-looking statements made in the presentation.
During this call, E*TRADE Financial now may also discuss the non-GAAP financial measures, and talk about its performance.  These measures will be reconciled to GAAP either during the course of this call, or in the companys press release, which can be found on its website at investor.etrade.com.
This call is being recorded.  Replay of this call will be available via phone, webcast, and podcast beginning this evening at approximately 7:00 p.m.  The call is being webcast live at investor.etrade.com.  No other recordings or copies of this call are authorized, or may be relied upon.  
And with that, I will now turn the call over to Steve Freiburg.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you everyone for joining us today.  To begin this afternoons call, I will cover highlights from the third quarter, and then Bruce will take you through the results.  From there, Ill share some thoughts on the opportunities we see for the bus
componenttext:
Thank you everyone for joining us today.  
To begin this afternoons call, I will cover highlights from the third quarter, and then Bruce will take you through the results.  From there, Ill share some thoughts on the opportunities we see for the business after which we will be happy to take your questions.
The third quarter was an important one for E*TRADE as we delivered our second consecutive quarterly profit.  We reported pre-tax income of 36 million, and achieved positive net income for the quarter despite an unusually reported tax rate.  
Strength in a number of areas supported our performance in a quarter that was notable for the industry-wide decline in trading activity, and a challenging interest rate environment.
We were pleased with the growth in net new assets, and average margin receivables, and with the quality of new accounts in the brokerage business.
Improvement in loan performance trends drove the eighth consecutive quarterly decline in our loan-loss provision.  Effective balance sheet strategies resulted in solid net interest income, and we benefited from opportunistic gains in our securities portfolio.
Our results demonstrated progress in positioning the company for sustainable profitability in growth as we continue to execute on a number of key objectives.  
Our provision for loan losses has been below charge-offs for five consecutive quarters.  We have generated organic-bank regulatory capital each quarter this year.  And we have delivered our second consecutive profitable quarter.
During the quarter, we executed on a number of initiatives to expand our offering to both active traders and long-term investors.  
In June, we released application programming interface for API, allowing third-party vendors and independent software developers to interface seamlessly with our investing platform.  
In September, we introduced new research and trade idea generation tools, including market commentary from Dreyfus and Buzz and Banta from Minyanville; a leading business and finance site.  
Also in September, we launched a new cross- media ad campaign including TV spots that are running during highly-rated fall sporting events and primetime programming.
The campaign with the tagline,  Investing Unleased, includes several new E*TRADE baby spots as well as product ads that speak directly to self-directed investors who are ready to take control of their finances.  It is a high-impact campaign that moves the brand forward and positions us well for the fourth quarter as well as 2011.
In addition, our ongoing investment in the overall customer experience including a growing relationship management team and simplified pricing continues to pay off.  This supported a sequential improvement in our annualized brokerage account attrition rate from 13% to 10%; our lowest attrition rate in more than six years, and a level we will strive to sustain over the long run.
We also received industry recognition for our Corporate Services Organization from Group Five, the leader in equity compensation research, which named us number one in overall satisfaction and loyalty for stock plan administration in its tenth-annual benchmarking survey.  
Our Corporate Services Group, which provides stock plan administrative tools and services continues to gain traction, and now counts 20% of the S&P 500 as clients.  This continues to be an attractive opportunity for us both as a standalone business, and as a meaningful source of new retail brokerage accounts.
With that, I will turn the call over to Bruce to take you through our results for the quarter.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you Steve.  While we were affected by the decline in overall trading, we were pleased with our results, which were supported by strength in our brokerage business, continued positive trends in our loan portfolio, and solid net interest income.We
componenttext:
Thank you Steve.  
While we were affected by the decline in overall trading, we were pleased with our results, which were supported by strength in our brokerage business, continued positive trends in our loan portfolio, and solid net interest income.
We reported net income of 8 million, or $0.03 per share during the third quarter, which compares with net income of 35 million, or $0.12 per share in the prior quarter, and a net loss of 855 million, or $6.74 per share in the third quarter of 2009.
Our Third Quarter 2009 results included a non-cash charge on debt exchange of 773 million, or $6.09 per share.  When excluding the impact of the debt exchange, we had a net loss of 82 million, or $0.65 per share in the third quarter of 2009.
We reported pre-tax income of 36 million for the quarter, but as Steve noted, we had an unusually high reported tax rate this quarter, so let me explain.  
Although our actual tax rate continues to be approximately 38%, our reported tax rate is much higher because certain of our expenses are not deductible for tax purposes.  For example and most importantly, about 1/3 of interest expense on the Springling Notes is not deductible for tax purposes.  Therefore, while our reported pre-tax income is 36 million, our income subject to taxation is higher resulting this quarter in a much higher reported tax rate of 76%.  This is due not only to the higher amount of taxable income, but also to the fact that our reported pre-tax income for the year is relatively close to break even.
The addition pre-tax income from the Springling notes is about 35 million per year.  And the annual tax on that income is about $10 million.  Therefore, this issue will be mitigated if our reported pre-tax income grows in the future.
We produced 489 million of net revenue during the quarter, a decline of 45 million from the prior quarter, and down 86 million, or 15% from the same quarter a year ago.  The decline in revenue was driven almost entirely by the decrease in trading activity as was experienced across the industry.
We were pleased to maintain a relatively consistent level of interest income of 299 million.  The 3 million decline from the prior quarter reflected a 1.3 billion decrease in average interest earning assets to 39.7 billion, which was largely offset by a six basis point expansion; a net interest spread to 2.95%.  This reflects our strategy of maintaining a relatively consistent net interest spread despite an environment of declining interest rates.
Commissions, fees, and service charges, principal transactions, and other revenue in the third quarter were 151 million.  This was down 23% compared to the prior quarter, and was impacted by the decline in DARTS, and a very slight decline in average commission per trade from $11.05 to $11.03.
Our revenue this quarter also included 40 million of net gains in loans and securities, including a net impairment of 7 million as we managed our investment portfolio to limit our risks and we realized gains due to favorable market opportunities.  This compares with 37 million of net gains in the second quarter, and 23 million in the third quarter of 2009.
Our total operating expense for the third quarter decline 3%, or 9 million from the prior quarter to 267 million, which represented a 12% decline from the third quarter of 2009.  This included lower compensation in clearing expense, as well as a 6 million credit against professional service fees as part of the legal settlement.
Lets turn now to metrics.  As noted, we experienced a slowdown in trading activity over the summer, certainly in comparison to record highs in recent years.  DARTS for the third quarter were 127,000, down 26% from the prior quarter, and down 30% compared with the third quarter of 2009.  
Nevertheless, we saw strength in a number of areas.  Net new asset flows into our brokerage business were a positive 1.4 billion during the quarter, and total 5.7 billion in year to date.  Net new brokerage accounts were 7,000, bringing account growth for the 27,000.   And we ended the quarter with a record 2.7 million brokerage accounts.  
Brokerage customer cash increased by 1.9 billion to 22.6 billion while customers were net sellers of 1.3 billion in securities.
Bank customer cash declined by 600 million.  In total, we experienced a net increase of 1.3 billion of customer cash deposits, which was a positive contributor to our net interest income.
Another positive contributor was increased margin loans to customers.  Average margin receivables grew by 4% during the quarter from 4.5 billion to 4.7 billion.  This represented a 52% increase from a year ago.
We were pleased with the performance of our loan portfolio.  The portfolio contracted by 1 billion during the quarter, and our loan loss provision declined from 166 million in the second quarter to 152 million in the third quarter.  This is the eighth consecutive quarterly decline in the provision, which is now 71% below its peak in the third quarter of 2008.
Loan charge-offs declined slightly from 225 million in the second quarter to 222 million in the third quarter.  This is the fifth consecutive quarterly decline, and charge-offs are now 43% below their peak of 386 million in the second quarter of 2009.
The allowance for loan losses ended the quarter at 1 billion, down 70 million from the prior quarter and remains at 6% of gross loans receivable.
We expect that credit costs will continue to decline.  However, because the timing and magnitude of the improvement is affected by many factors, we anticipate variability in any one quarter, while continued to see a downward trend over the long-term.
Related to the recent decisions by a number of banks to suspend or review their foreclosure programs, we do not expect any material direct impact, although we may indirectly affected as any delays work their way through the system.  
As a reminder, E*TRADE does not service any of its loan portfolio and we rely exclusively on third-party services.  
We are pleased that the bank generated capital again this quarter.  The bank generated 81 million in regulatory risk-based capital bringing the year-to-date total to 191 million.  As of September 30, the Tier 1 capital ratio was 7.14% to total adjusted assets, and 13.75% to risk weighted assets.  We ended the quarter with 1.1 billion of risk-based total capital in excess of the level that our regulators defined as well capitalized.
On a consolidated basis, we ended the quarter with 1.5 billion in tier one capital, and our tangible common equity was 2.1 billion, both slightly higher than second quarter levels.
We ended the quarter with 490 million in corporate cash.  This is an increase of approximately 9 million from the prior quarter, and included a 31, or $34 million dividend from the bank.
Finally, I want to note that our corporate interest income this quarter benefited by 6 million from a legal settlement.  
In all, we were very pleased with our performance in the quarter, and look forward to building on our momentum.  
And with that, I will turn the call back to Steve for additional remarks.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you Bruce.Before opening the call for questions, I would like to share a few comments related to future plans and initiatives.When we spoke last quarter, I had been on board approximately 100 days, and we had just reported our first quarter of p
componenttext:
Thank you Bruce.
Before opening the call for questions, I would like to share a few comments related to future plans and initiatives.
When we spoke last quarter, I had been on board approximately 100 days, and we had just reported our first quarter of profitability in three years.  The company has achieved a number of important milestones allowing us to shift gears from defense to offense.  And providing the flexibility to review opportunities for future growth.
We since have focused on areas where we see potential for driving enhanced growth and profitability.  I will highlight four categories.
First, we have a solid retail brokerage franchise that has performed extremely well throughout its history, most recently contributing great results that were often over shadowed by challenges in the loan portfolio.  With a base of all-time high 2.7 million brokerage accounts complemented by an enhanced marketing spend, we believe there are continued opportunities to expand our relationship sales, products, and service initiatives to grow our active trader and long-term investor customer basis.
Our growing sales force will emphasize long-term investor retirement solutions, including the advisor based managed investment portfolios, as well as a full suite of fund and fixed-income brokerage product offerings.
We will also continue to expand our offering for active traders and are in the early launch phase of portfolio margin in three or four option spreads, E*TRADE communities, and additions to our mobile trading applications specifically E*TRADE Mobile Pro for Android.
On the marketing side as I mentioned earlier, we have been evolving our advertising to include product and service focused messaging in addition to iconic E*TRADE Baby.  And we believe we have a terrific opportunity to better engage with the 15 million prospects that visit our website each year.
Second, we have significant institutional brokerage opportunities, notably our Corporate Services and Capital Markets Groups.  Both these businesses have scaled and are market leaders. 
Our corporate services group continues to make progress with new and expanded businesses in both software and services.  And is an important source of new retail brokerage accounts.
Our capital markets group also provides a strong foundation for organic growth in our market making activities.  We are completing effectively, and acquiring more external order flow.  We will continue to insure we are extracting maximum economic benefit from our retail customer engagement.  
Third, as we continue to expand our wealth management offering for long-term investors via existing sales and service channels, we will leverage our heritage of innovation with an eye toward delivering value propositions that we define the customer experience for self-directed investors.
E*TRADE was a pioneer in online trading, and we believe that we have an opportunity to play a similar role in online investing as customer needs and technologies evolve. 
Finally, we believe our bank can play an important role in helping us to optimize the value of our very large and stable brokerage customer deposit base.  
With a focus on these four areas, which build on our current strengths, and many cases existing assets, we are optimistic about the opportunities ahead.  We are actively executing against these growth strategies, and well keep you informed on our progress.  As we do this, I assure you that we will remain intensely focused on flawless execution and rigorous expensed management.  I am gratified to see the energy across the organization as we seize the growth opportunities that lie ahead for E*TRADE.
With that operator, we are ready to take questions.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if we could start on the net interest margin.  One of the things that weve seen across the sector is that re-investment risk is coming to the floor in terms of how you think about loans rolling off and where youre reinvesting those d
componenttext: I was wondering if we could start on the net interest margin.  One of the things that weve seen across the sector is that re-investment risk is coming to the floor in terms of how you think about loans rolling off and where youre reinvesting those dollars.  So could you sort of remind us again how youre thinking about your strategy going forward here?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah.  First we agreed that our preference is to have basically this distinctive upwards slope on the yield curve and you know, it elevated the level of brace, which clearly has been part of the challenge that Bruce alluded to during the quarter.  You k
componenttext:
Yeah.  First we agreed that our preference is to have basically this distinctive upwards slope on the yield curve and you know, it elevated the level of brace, which clearly has been part of the challenge that Bruce alluded to during the quarter.  
You know, that said, weve done several things that helped maintain basically the net-interest margin, and in fact improved the net-interest margin during the period.  You know at first, which I think is strategic for us.  You know, we continue to basically grow our margin book, which is actually important.  
Second, we basically have the opportunity that weve executed on to deploy investment strategies and keep cash at a lower level than we might have otherwise, but sufficient to run our businesses.  So cash basically is earning very little in the overall business. 
And finally, we have had the opportunity to basically invest as you know in agency-backed securities, which is essentially where we invest our excess as our legacy-loan portfolios come down.  And I think basically our treasury area has played essentially that role of basically smart lead and its done very well in that pursuit.  
Bruce said on the call pretty much that we would strive to keep our net-interest margin in roughly the 300 basis point range.  You know, obviously theres no precision around 300, but we would say that we have a level of confidence that we will maintain it within that range, plus or minus, but we strive to stay relatively neutral on rate moves in either direction.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay.  Thanks, thats really helpful.  You know, one of the things Ive heard you say, Steve, is that you, having spent some time looking through the bank, theres clearly a good bank within E*TRADE, especially for those clients that are probably ba
componenttext:
Okay.  Thanks, thats really helpful.  You know, one of the things Ive heard you say, Steve, is that you, having spent some time looking through the bank, theres clearly a good bank within E*TRADE, especially for those clients that are probably bank and brokerage accounts.  
You know, have you guys done any more work on identifying that, you know, whats the size of that portfolio and how would you think about monetizing that further?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah, let me answer.  For the broader audience, its that we have, since my arrival, done segmentation work on what could be described as good-bank bad-bank and without going through detail, either analysis or numbers, as expected embedded in the roughl
componenttext:
Yeah, let me answer.  For the broader audience, its that we have, since my arrival, done segmentation work on what could be described as good-bank bad-bank and without going through detail, either analysis or numbers, as expected embedded in the roughly $17 billion legacy portfolio there are a larger number of customers of E*TRADE that have very good profiles both from the standpoint of how they look on their own, basically either I would say FICO, demographic and other.  And in addition to that theyve had basically consistent level of payment history with us and theres absolutely nothing wrong with them and if we had a choice wed rather maintain them longer than shorter.  
So you know, that said, now that we have a view of good-bank bad-bank we are looking at and evaluating strategies that might allow us to optimize within, but its a bit premature to go into any detail related to that other than just say that the 17 billion or so is not a model and within that theres opportunity.  And when were basically further down the line wed be more than pleased to have a broader dialog on that topic.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010

componenttext:
Just a question on the home equity loans.  Theres just a slight uptick in the special-mention loans on home equity and then Im also looking at the - the allowance on the modified loans, on the TDRs.  That looked like the allowance will increase 11%. 
So I guess can you just comment on where you think the credit situation is going on with home equity?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hi.  Yeah, this is Paul Brandow.  Ill comment on that.  So we are actually overall very pleased with the performance in delinquencies over this year.  I think total special mention including both First Lane and Home Equity are down in the neighborhood
componenttext:
Hi.  Yeah, this is Paul Brandow.  Ill comment on that.  So we are actually overall very pleased with the performance in delinquencies over this year.  I think total special mention including both First Lane and Home Equity are down in the neighborhood of 25%.  
You are right, the improvement more recently in Home Equity has been flatter than First Lane, than what we expected because of our First Lane portfolio is better seasoned so it took longer time for some of the core credits to run through there.  
But where we are now, its still believing that were within this long-term trend, but there will be variability from month to month so youre right, in September there was what I would call a fairly modest uptick but if you look over the past four, five or six months, the trend has been flattest to down. 
So I dont think that will change, but we think the rate of improvement, particularly in Home Equity would probably be more moderate.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, just on the TRD allowance for home equity -
componenttext: Well, just on the TRD allowance for home equity -

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The TDR allowance, the home equity, the allowances did go up.  I dont know where you got that 11% from.  The evaluation I think went from 50% at the end of last quarter to 55% at the end of this quarter.  Thats very much consistent with our experien
componenttext: The TDR allowance, the home equity, the allowances did go up.  I dont know where you got that 11% from.  The evaluation I think went from 50% at the end of last quarter to 55% at the end of this quarter.  Thats very much consistent with our experience with regard to delinquencies and so while it is up, its sort of within the range of what we expected.  And our performance with regard to re-delinquencies and modified loans, we believe to be considerably better than what we can glean as in terms of overall market performance.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay.  And then I guess Bruce, or Steve, I think you alluded to this, but the cash that you invested, it looks like on the bank average, you know, enterprise balance sheet that a significant amount of cash was deployed.  And I guess can you just talk abou
componenttext: Okay.  And then I guess Bruce, or Steve, I think you alluded to this, but the cash that you invested, it looks like on the bank average, you know, enterprise balance sheet that a significant amount of cash was deployed.  And I guess can you just talk about - it looked like it went down on average, you know 2.3 billion out of cash and cash equivalence into - at least a portion of it into other investments.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes.  In fact, if you recall in the last earnings forecast that we gave in discussion with you we talked about one of our goals was to redeploy more of our cash and not to have as much as it at the low return and we were successful. Frankly, we still ha
componenttext:
Yes.  In fact, if you recall in the last earnings forecast that we gave in discussion with you we talked about one of our goals was to redeploy more of our cash and not to have as much as it at the low return and we were successful. 
Frankly, we still have more to go.  Its always difficult to determine how much cash youre going to have to reinvest and we did have those securities gains so we ended up with more than we would have like and we still seem more upside in redeploying cash into more lucrative investments going forward.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay.  And the very last quick question, why isnt the interest expense for the Springling Notes deductible?
componenttext: Okay.  And the very last quick question, why isnt the interest expense for the Springling Notes deductible?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Right.  Theres really a restriction by the Internal Revenue Service as to how much of high-yield debt interest can be deductible.  So its a combination of the rate plus to the extent that you have original issue discount. And just to clarify, I wa
componenttext:
Right.  Theres really a restriction by the Internal Revenue Service as to how much of high-yield debt interest can be deductible.  So its a combination of the rate plus to the extent that you have original issue discount. 
And just to clarify, I want to make sure I said the right number.  Its 12 million is the tax that would due to this non-deductible interest.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Rich, this is Steve.  Just to add to Bruces commentary that its roughly 1/3 of the interest is not deductible, not the interest overall.
componenttext: Rich, this is Steve.  Just to add to Bruces commentary that its roughly 1/3 of the interest is not deductible, not the interest overall.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Right.
componenttext: Right.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And so its that third as well as the original that you discount that is getting advertised out and clearly its not deductible.  Obviously when the firm was losing money, it was neither an issue and/or obvious.  The real challenge is when essentially
componenttext: And so its that third as well as the original that you discount that is getting advertised out and clearly its not deductible.  Obviously when the firm was losing money, it was neither an issue and/or obvious.  The real challenge is when essentially the profitability is relatively small that you know, the 12 million effect of this gets magnified on a relative basis, which is the tax rate.  And over the longer term, assuming a company returns to normal levels of profitability it becomes relatively mild.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010

componenttextpreview: Continuing on the technical part of the tax, is it 12 per quarter or 12 per year?  I heard you say earlier it was annually?
componenttext: Continuing on the technical part of the tax, is it 12 per quarter or 12 per year?  I heard you say earlier it was annually?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thats correct, Eric.  Maybe I can anticipate your question.  The way you do your taxes, each quarter you have to do an estimate of the annual pre-tax income thats taxable and your annual tax payment and then that gets run through your quarterly stat
componenttext:
Thats correct, Eric.  Maybe I can anticipate your question.  The way you do your taxes, each quarter you have to do an estimate of the annual pre-tax income thats taxable and your annual tax payment and then that gets run through your quarterly statement and in an one quarter you can end up with wild swings and the impact, and that was the case this quarter.  
The overall, if youre doing an annual forecast, you should assume 12 million as an incremental above and beyond a typical 38 percent effective tax rate.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010

componenttextpreview: Oh, thank you very much.  Getting into the NIM again, following up on Dans question earlier, are you suggesting that NIM will not compress if we continue to see the yield curve stay where it is, or even press a little bit lower over the next year or so
componenttext: Oh, thank you very much.  Getting into the NIM again, following up on Dans question earlier, are you suggesting that NIM will not compress if we continue to see the yield curve stay where it is, or even press a little bit lower over the next year or so, you know, with quantitive reason?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I think what we said, which is consistent with last quarter that, you know, we expect to have basically a NIM in the 300 basis point range as our goal.  Were close to that now even with the challenges that the industry as well as E*TRADE faced in t
componenttext: No, I think what we said, which is consistent with last quarter that, you know, we expect to have basically a NIM in the 300 basis point range as our goal.  Were close to that now even with the challenges that the industry as well as E*TRADE faced in the second quarter.  But in any given quarter, any given period it can vary from that.  And so we cant guarantee 300 but I would say that were striving hard to maintain consistency on our spread.  And as you recall, 289 did grow to 295 and were working hard to maintain our spreads.  But to point, we are basically subject to re-investment risks and the environment.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: So let me ask it a different way then.  If the rate environment that we have today persists and doesnt change, you know, how much downside is there to NIM as you reprice to the existing rate curve?
componenttext: So let me ask it a different way then.  If the rate environment that we have today persists and doesnt change, you know, how much downside is there to NIM as you reprice to the existing rate curve?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The question is clear, I just dont feel comfortable giving you a quantitative or quantified answer to it.  But I can tell you directionally, you know, in the stable rate environment today, we feel that there is stability in our spreads.  Again, it may
componenttext:
The question is clear, I just dont feel comfortable giving you a quantitative or quantified answer to it.  But I can tell you directionally, you know, in the stable rate environment today, we feel that there is stability in our spreads.  Again, it may not be precise, but there is stability in our spreads.  
If the environment were to say flatten from here, clearly re-investment risk is real and if rates basically would rise with time given the average duration of our portfolio is about 3, 3  years, you can get a sense of any given period what were reinvesting.

componenttext: Okay.  Ill squeeze in one more.

One other thing to add is that it will also be a function of to the extent we realize the gains because right now we have seen good gains in the portfolio and were always making an economic decision as to whether its best lock in some of those gains versus having the interest income flow in future quarters.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010

componenttext: Okay.  Lastly, on the liability side, youre deposit balances and rate continue to compress.  Is that still desirable from a capital-ratio perspective, or is this a business decision that you want to continue shrinking your deposit base and your exposure to that very low cost of funding?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I say at this point, Eric, that were having the deposits come from brokerage customers and were making money on all of those deposits.  So theres not the same desire to reduce the deposits.  Theres some natural runoff on the bank side but you
componenttext:
I say at this point, Eric, that were having the deposits come from brokerage customers and were making money on all of those deposits.  So theres not the same desire to reduce the deposits.  Theres some natural runoff on the bank side but you saw that overall customer cash was quite strong that you had actually an increase this quarter.
And from our broad standpoint, thats a good thing.  And as we said, we still generated organic capital despite this increase in assets and that to us is the best in both worlds.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hi.  Good afternoon.  Given all thats going on in D.C., Im just curious, any clarity on whether youll ultimately maintain your thrift charter?  Do you envision any shifts to that charter?  And with the $40 billion balance sheet, do you think th
componenttext:
Hi.  Good afternoon.  Given all thats going on in D.C., Im just curious, any clarity on whether youll ultimately maintain your thrift charter?  Do you envision any shifts to that charter?  
And with the $40 billion balance sheet, do you think theres a probability - or a high probability youll be deemed systemically important?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: From the standpoint of our charter, we dont see any either issues or risk to our charter.  You know, obviously what we do know, you know, factually is that the OTS will become an operating arm of the OCC basically I think through the later part of next
componenttext:
From the standpoint of our charter, we dont see any either issues or risk to our charter.  You know, obviously what we do know, you know, factually is that the OTS will become an operating arm of the OCC basically I think through the later part of next year.  
But that said, our expectation would be that we are basically a well-capitalized banking institution with a purpose and that should not basically have any adverse impact as the OTS moves under the OCC.  I dont know how else to answer that question.  At this point we have every degree of confidence that weve operated well with our current regulator and well operate well with whatever the succession time will be.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay.  Thanks, Steven.  And just a follow up on that comment with regards to well-capitalized.  I guess Don Frank seems to focus a lot on parent-company capital.  Given your view that youve got excess capital within the bank, whats the appetite and
componenttext: Okay.  Thanks, Steven.  And just a follow up on that comment with regards to well-capitalized.  I guess Don Frank seems to focus a lot on parent-company capital.  Given your view that youve got excess capital within the bank, whats the appetite and the ability to really upstream that at this point into the parent co?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, at this point all I can say is that we are in a position with excess capital, were generating organic capital each quarter but at this point I just cannot give you any forecast as to when we may be able to take money up from the bank to the paren
componenttext: Well, at this point all I can say is that we are in a position with excess capital, were generating organic capital each quarter but at this point I just cannot give you any forecast as to when we may be able to take money up from the bank to the parent.  I mean, thats down the road.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Im mean, to actuate without predicting, as youd expect clearly its our preference to upstream capital over time, which provides us more flexibility as well as the opportunity to have not only a well-capitalized bank, but a well-capitalized holdin
componenttext: Im mean, to actuate without predicting, as youd expect clearly its our preference to upstream capital over time, which provides us more flexibility as well as the opportunity to have not only a well-capitalized bank, but a well-capitalized holding company as well.  So these are - these are basically areas were actively engaged but its premature to basically bring either specificity to it prediction particularly around time.  But the, you know, the issue is one that we have as priority.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, guys.  Thanks for the detail on the future plans and areas to focus on, its helpful.  Just on that point, just when we think about the balance sheet, you know, it has been running off about a billion a quarter.  Is that still, you know, sort of
componenttext: Thanks, guys.  Thanks for the detail on the future plans and areas to focus on, its helpful.  Just on that point, just when we think about the balance sheet, you know, it has been running off about a billion a quarter.  Is that still, you know, sort of an expected run rate in the near term?  Or just if you do just deposits would you be keeping it at a certain level, more from just a forecasting standpoint?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah.  I think the best way to think about it is the Legacy Asset Portfolio should continue to run off at approximately a billion dollars a quarter although, not in perpetuity obviously, the portfolio gets smaller and its sort of a relative adjustment
componenttext:
Yeah.  I think the best way to think about it is the Legacy Asset Portfolio should continue to run off at approximately a billion dollars a quarter although, not in perpetuity obviously, the portfolio gets smaller and its sort of a relative adjustment to that.  But Id say that you know, the trend has been approximately a billion a quarter and probably holds for a while and then diminished in absolute terms just by nature of size of the portfolio. 
On the other side, and kind of basically picking up on Bruces commentary, we would expect and strategically want to grow our consumer deposit base, particularly our consumer deposits coming from our brokerage business.  That said, as those deposits grow and they have been growing, we probably will diminish, which is what we have been doing as well.  And hopefully we will grow the business, and I think the balance sheet, over a longer term will be more determined by the size of our customer deposits, strategic customer deposits than anything else and will adjust the asset side of the balance sheet accordingly.  
So hopefully, you know, with time well may see assets come down, wholesale funding comes down, customer deposits go up and well build the asset side of the balance see in accordance to the size of that space.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks.  Thats helpful.  And then just one more on the - I guess on the capital side.  You now, we think about if you had either like a target for the holding company, you know, if we think about whether the amount of capital in the bank, earning
componenttext: Okay, thanks.  Thats helpful.  And then just one more on the - I guess on the capital side.  You now, we think about if you had either like a target for the holding company, you know, if we think about whether the amount of capital in the bank, earnings generation, the DTA benefit, you can kind of back into it, but I dont know if you guys have some sense or maybe you will in a few quarters down the road if you get more clarity but Im just wondering your thoughts on that because there are a lot of moving pieces.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: At this point were monitoring what the regulatory requirements are going to be, but in general the only thing we know for sure is that therell be similar ratios to whats applied to the bank and so were already just making sure that we have for
componenttext: At this point were monitoring what the regulatory requirements are going to be, but in general the only thing we know for sure is that therell be similar ratios to whats applied to the bank and so were already just making sure that we have forecasted good Tier 1 capital as a percent of total assets and good Tier 1 capital as percent of risk weighted out.  And we also pay attention to tangible equity as another ratio that makes since.  We havent set specific targets but from all the commentary weve seen about potential goals that maybe set by regulators, we feel very confident that over time we should be able to maintain and fulfill any requirement without the need for external capital.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010

componenttext: Okay, thats helpful.  And just on expenses, you know, continue to trend down and you guys are finding ways to take it down, this quarter you have some seasonality.  I guess just going towards maybe the lift up in advertising that we typically see, you know, anything unusual there or any other laydowns from other initiatives that are in place?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: At this point we think relatively constant expected, theres be some mix changes as weve talked that more emphasis on customer facing and customer service people as opposed to back-office people.  But the heavy lifting on the overall reduction expens
componenttext: At this point we think relatively constant expected, theres be some mix changes as weve talked that more emphasis on customer facing and customer service people as opposed to back-office people.  But the heavy lifting on the overall reduction expenses has occurred and therell be more just, as Steve put it, managing our expenses to make sure that we dont increase them as our profitability improves.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah, and just to add to that, you know, the general mode of operation for us is going to be - is to redirect expenses into growth opportunities both short and intermediate term and hopefully that will basically enhance the trajectory of the business.  Yo
componenttext: Yeah, and just to add to that, you know, the general mode of operation for us is going to be - is to redirect expenses into growth opportunities both short and intermediate term and hopefully that will basically enhance the trajectory of the business.  You know, its not so much expenses, theres good expenses and bad expenses.  We want to make sure that we have an overabundance of good expense in the business and really drive down the expenses that are not adding value or distracting.

componenttext: Okay.  Thanks, guys.

componenttext: That is.  Theres really two different topics.  There is one which is corporate interest expense and that had a credit from the legal settlement.  The prior discussion was on our net interest spread and that referred to cash primarily in our bank and so that would not be effected by the credit.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I understand.  Okay, thank you.  And then on the drop in your attrition rate at the brokerage, obviously pretty impressive in 13 to 10.  Can you clarify at all how big of impact the fact that you guys basically started waving IRA service fees and account
componenttext: I understand.  Okay, thank you.  And then on the drop in your attrition rate at the brokerage, obviously pretty impressive in 13 to 10.  Can you clarify at all how big of impact the fact that you guys basically started waving IRA service fees and account service fees, I guess the first and second quarters.  Did that then play a role because youre not pushing people down below the $25 minimum on your own, theyre just kind of staying in lower-balance accounts?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah.  This is Steve again.  You know, clearly its not one element that brings down the rate, but clearly thats been helpful.  I think simplifying our pricing, basically taking off the inactivity fees.  But I think more importantly where we measure
componenttext:
Yeah.  This is Steve again.  You know, clearly its not one element that brings down the rate, but clearly thats been helpful.  I think simplifying our pricing, basically taking off the inactivity fees.  But I think more importantly where we measure essentially the service satisfaction of our client base thats been on a constant - basically constantly improving.  The voting scores, not necessarily not only how people feel about the firm but willing to recommend us to others, thats improving as well.  Plus weve been enhancing both product as well as utility, which is our platform.  I think its really kind of the aggregation of all those pieces that have brought the attrition rate down to what has been a goal for the company.  
And also actually, you know, quite an impressive march from where it had been if you look back over the last six quarters or so to where it is today.  As I said, in the opening commentary, our expectation is well strive hard to maintain it.  Id like to say well try hard to improve upon it to get into the single digits, but its a big deal when you have 2.7 million brokerage accounts, every 1% is a lot of accounts if you think about it in essentially the merit terms.  If you think about 1%, its 27,000 accounts, how much we spend to get 27,000 accounts.  
So what were trying to operate on, not only is the front end, bringing on new customers but bringing on new customers and really maintain the relationship we have with our existing customers.  And importantly, [inaudible] out the relationship we have with the existing customers so we can help them further and we can derive more benefit as they derive basically up more utility from what we offer.  But its all wrapped together.

componenttext: Typically, and it varies a bit, but typically 20 to 25 percent of our new retail accounts comes through that stream.  And so in a world where everyone has limits to resources, that has become a very high priority for us; one, to grow the business because on its own its compelling.  But more importantly its one of the best sources of good quality new customers that we have and we have a very strong presence within that space.  And in addition to that, it was probably the largest single capital expenditure this company has made over the last 2  years which completely updated its capabilities and platforms as well as its people.  And its been recognized externally and we see it as an important leverage of growth of business, and were very excited about it and were working very hard on that aspect as we speak.

componenttext: Yeah, hi.  Good evening.  I have a follow-up question for Steve on capital.  Once you are actually able to upstream the capital, can you give us a sense as to what your views are and how youd allocate them?  I guess what Im asking, you have debt thats callable next year and could argue that the stocks looking pretty attractive on normalized earnings and how you weight that versus kind of basil requirements?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah, I just know we look at it, you know, I would say on a hypothetical because clearly we have an upstream to capital at this point.  But if we were to upstream capital, we think about it as potentially having three - lets say three uses.  You know,
componenttext:
Yeah, I just know we look at it, you know, I would say on a hypothetical because clearly we have an upstream to capital at this point.  But if we were to upstream capital, we think about it as potentially having three - lets say three uses.  You know, one is we want to basically grow the business and how much capital is required to grow the business, although largely this is not a highly capital intensive business.  Second to your point, we have a sizable amount of high-priced debt out in the marketplace and if we could retire some of that debt, that would be a good thing because we spend pretty close to $170 million or so a year servicing that debt, which was brought on largely when the company was stressed and needed to be recapped. 
And then finally to your point, you know, we would basically look at alternatives including the potential to buy back our own equity or stock.  But it will be situational so when the events occur, its hard to predict which would have the highest priority, but I think the universe is reasonably well defined as to what we might deploy that capital towards.  
So Im not abating, but I cant answer the question until I get to the point where I actually have the capital from the standpoint of flexibility, but also understand the situation at that particular point in time.

componenttext:
Let me give a try at that answer.  This is Paul again.  So if youre looking at the exhibit in our press release, youre right.  Theres two columns.  Ones a specific allowance, a percentage of the loans and one is the total expected loss.  The difference between those two numbers is due to the fact that at 180 days past due, we write all of our loans down to expected recovery value.  
So basically, the difference between those columns is that.  The ultimate column, the specific valuation represents the reserve we have for the remaining losses we expect to take on those loans and that allowance we do believe its sufficient to cover those losses.

componenttextpreview: This is Steve.  Let me try to provide perspective to that.  The business that E*TRADE has been in, which is predominately the purchase of whole loans and securities, is a business that we would not re-enter, definitely would not re-enter.  To quality, age
componenttext:
This is Steve.  Let me try to provide perspective to that.  The business that E*TRADE has been in, which is predominately the purchase of whole loans and securities, is a business that we would not re-enter, definitely would not re-enter.  To quality, agency-backed MBS is fine. 
From the standpoint more broadly, would we like to lend money to our high-quality brokerage customers?  Thats a different issue, and one that we are basically assessing.  So simply stated, we have a margin book, as we said, thats approaching 5 billion.  Would I like it to be twice the size?  The answer is yes.  Well be deploying additional product and capability as I mentioned over the coming quarters, hopefully giving us an opportunity to grow that up further.  
And then taking a step back, the universe that were quite interested in is largely the one that is the core of our business, the 2.7 million brokerage customers and well assess whether or not.  Were not saying we would, but well assess whether or not that is a business that wed want to enter.  If we would enter the lending business, it would be very much focused on that client base, which is a very different animal from where weve come, expectation being of a relational oriented business to a high quality basic customer could provide us an opportunity, but its something that were thinking about but we dont have specific plans to pursue.

componenttext:
Hey, good afternoon, guys.  Steve, in your prepared comments, you talked a little bit about some of your new growth initiatives and one that you touched on was advisor-based managed portfolios.  I was hoping you could provide a little bit more color on that.  And then just address the bigger issue where if you look at some of your - the larger competitors in the space, the firms that are growing the client assets the fastest certainly have the advisor businesses.  
So kind of how do you think about maybe trying to establish a bigger head into that area?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me answer both and Mike Curcio is here who runs the brokerage side and Mike, feel free to add comments as well. On the RAA business, it hasnt been a business that weve been in in the past.  Our business model really has been one thats direc
componenttext:
Let me answer both and Mike Curcio is here who runs the brokerage side and Mike, feel free to add comments as well. 
On the RAA business, it hasnt been a business that weve been in in the past.  Our business model really has been one thats direct to the customer.  And so not disagreeing that its a fast or growing segment of the broader industry, it just hasnt been an area that weve pursued.  So its something that, again, we would consider but in a world of prioritization, its not high on our list of priorities at least over the near-to-intermediate term.  
In contrast, for example, we would much prefer to rev up or Corporate Services group and grow more rapidly there than basically enter an area that is costly to enter and will take a long time in our view to get out of it profitability.  So we just have to be conscious, not only of the opportunity but the cost of entering and what our alternatives are.  And again, because it wasnt central to the business model overtime, Ill never say never, but I dont want to mislead anybody to say that were going to jump into that area.  
From the standpoint of managed investment products and the like, Ill let Mike comment on that as to what we have in the marketplace, how we basically have distributed those products and what some of the near-term opportunities are in that particular space as we try to base service both the investment needs of our clients in addition to what we historically have done which has been predominately the trading needs of our clients.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve.  This is Mike.  On the MIPs, or Managed Investment Portfolios, we first started with a very simple route, ETF and mutual accounts and were extended to - we will be extending to separately managed accounts in late Q4, early Q1 of next yea
componenttext:
Thanks, Steve.  This is Mike.  On the MIPs, or Managed Investment Portfolios, we first started with a very simple route, ETF and mutual accounts and were extended to - we will be extending to separately managed accounts in late Q4, early Q1 of next year.  
What weve seen is a tremendous appetite from our customer base.  Were hitting our numbers and in conjunction with rapidly extending our sales force, were very optimistic of more penetration and assets in MITs as well as their mutual fund business overall.

componenttext: Let me just go back just to add to the commentary that may have been missed.  Its what I said in my opening comments, that weve worked through a segmentation of our portfolio and in our - basically, I would say in our most compelling segments, what Mike and team have been doing is adding relational sales capability.  And in the addition of the relationship additionally sales capability, the fund actually services that we better serve not only the trading needs, but the investment needs of our customers as well.  Its a fairly virtuous cycle that they basically broaden their relationship with us, we can fulfill more of their needs, but in addition to that, we can begin to diversify just the transaction orientation on the brokerage side to one that gives us an actuarial stream in addition because of essentially the management feed that come along with those particular products.
